thread.title: Homes are less likely now than at any time since start of Great Recession to be in foreclosure
thread.title_full: Homes are less likely now than at any time since start of Great Recession to be in foreclosure - MarketWatch

author: By     Ruth Mantell
title: Homes are less likely now than at any time since start of Great Recession to be in foreclosure
text:
U.S. homes are today less likely to be in the foreclosure process than at any time since the Great Recession started, as a strengthening jobs environment helps families in many parts of the country better afford their monthly bills, according to data released Tuesday.
‘With 3 million jobs created during the past year, the improving labor market has helped more borrowers stay current on their mortgage loan.’ Frank Nothaft, CoreLogic About 1.3% of all mortgaged homes were in the foreclosure process in May — the smallest share since the end of 2007, when the downturn started, according to CoreLogic, an Irvine, Calif.–based analysis firm. A year earlier, the foreclosure-inventory rate was 1.7%.
“With 3 million jobs created during the past year, the improving labor market has helped more borrowers stay current on their mortgage loan,” said Frank Nothaft, CoreLogic’s chief economist.
Foreclosures were completed on about 41,000 homes in May, down 19% from a year earlier and 65% from a peak, which was hit in 2010.
More jobs aren’t the only factor behind families avoiding foreclosure. Climbing home prices are helping, too. As property values rise, struggling owners gain equity, enabling them to sell their homes without taking a loss and move to more affordable places.
The passage of time is also behind improving foreclosure trends. It’s been about nine years since the housing bubble burst, and the pool of troubled properties has narrowed.
CoreLogic The share of mortgaged homes in each state in the foreclosure process. New Jersey had the highest rate, at 4.9% in May. However, there are still elevated levels of distressed homeowners in the U.S., especially in certain areas. May’s 41,000 completed foreclosures were about double the monthly average of 21,000 in the years leading up to the bust.
States with the highest share of mortgaged properties in the foreclosure process in May were New Jersey, at 4.9%; New York, at 3.7%; and Florida, at 2.9%. Each of these markets is a “judicial” state, meaning that lenders must submit delinquency records to courts to move forward with the foreclosure process. Involving the courts tends to lead to longer foreclosure time lines and can upwardly skew data, CoreLogic noted.

Just five states, including Nevada and Florida, account for almost one-third of negative equity in the U.S. CoreLogic Meanwhile, certain markets that were hit particularly hard when the bubble burst make up a disproportionately large share of troubled homeowners. Just five states, including the likes of Nevada and Florida, account for almost one-third of negative equity in the U.S., according to another CoreLogic report. Negative equity means that a borrower owes more on a mortgage that a property is worth.
